D1.label: US Defence Contract Pipeline Secures Multi-Year Revenue
D1.description: A$13.1B order book converts at contracted margins; TAGOS-23 and follow-on programmes extend the US revenue runway
D1.plain_english: This is the bull case — Austal's near-monopoly in US aluminium naval shipbuilding gives it captive multi-year revenue. The order book covers 15+ years at current delivery rates.
D1.what_to_watch: TAGOS-23 contract award (expected H2 2026); US NDAA appropriations for Austal-relevant vessel types.
D1.upside: Re-rating toward A$7.50-8.00 if TAGOS-23 awarded and FY26 EBIT guidance delivered.
D1.risk_plain: If TAGOS-23 is awarded to a competitor, the US revenue gap becomes structural.

D2.label: AUKUS / Australian Defence Uplift Creates Domestic Pipeline
D2.description: AUKUS and Australian Defence Strategic Review commitments drive domestic surface fleet work to Austal Henderson
D2.plain_english: Australia's A$368B AUKUS commitment and defence budget expansion create a long-dated option for Henderson shipyard work. Not a current earnings driver but a structural tailwind.
D2.what_to_watch: ADCP surface fleet contract announcements; Henderson shipyard contract awards FY26-FY28.
D2.upside: Henderson becomes a material revenue contributor by FY28-FY30 as AUKUS industrial capacity builds.
D2.risk_plain: If all defence funding is absorbed by nuclear submarines, surface fleet work at Henderson remains minimal.

D3.label: US Revenue Gap Creates Earnings Cliff
D3.description: LCS programme wind-down and EPF completion create underutilisation at US facilities before new programmes (TAGOS-23) ramp
D3.plain_english: The bear case on revenue timing — if new programmes are delayed or awarded elsewhere, Austal's US yards face a gap between current work rolling off and new work starting.
D3.what_to_watch: LCS and EPF delivery completion dates; TAGOS-23 award timeline; Austal Mobile utilisation commentary.
D3.risk_plain: US facility underutilisation drives fixed cost absorption issues and EBIT collapse in FY27-FY28.

D4.label: Fixed-Price Contracts Recur with Cost Overruns + Governance
D4.description: T-ATS accounting error is not isolated; further control failures or cost overruns in US operations destroy earnings quality and management credibility
D4.plain_english: The governance bear case — the US$17.1M T-ATS double-counting may signal systemic internal control issues. If a second error emerges, the market will severely punish the stock.
D4.what_to_watch: Any further accounting disclosures; FY26 EBIT delivery vs A$110M guidance; DoD audit activity.
D4.risk_plain: A second accounting error or DoD audit issue would trigger a 30-40% de-rating and management change.

big_picture: Austal Limited (ASX: ASB) — 1HFY26 EPS A$0.16 (+99% beat), order book A$13.1B. EBIT guidance cut from A$135M to A$110M due to US$17.1M T-ATS accounting error. AUKUS and US Navy pipeline de-risk the revenue case; governance controls are the key watch.
